body:
Is this a problem you're observing in practice?

This is a known aspect of the design as it currently stands. The problem here is that there isn't a single good heuristic here to use in terms of cleaning out these caches, as they are in a particularly hot portion of the rendering code. We also just mechanically don't have a great way to track despawns. For example, removing a material component doesn't necessarily mean that we should remove you from the cache, as you might just be switching material types for a few frames, etc. For many applications, paying the cost of the hash lookups to keep the cache clean isn't worth the memory savings.

However, it's also true that applications that are particularly churn-y with respect to spawning/despawning entities could be affected by memory growth. The solution here likely is to expose some kind of mechanism that a particular application could use to flush the rendering caches on some kind of timer and just pay the cost of rebuilding the entire cache. Or when changing scenes, etc.

I guess we could maybe use `OnDespawn` on `Mesh3d` in order to create a batch list of entities to flush from the cache every N frames. We would have to iterate all the views in order to evict the pipeline caches though.

> Is this a problem you're observing in practice?

My application definitely falls into the "particularly churn-y" category and is intended for low-memory environments (mobile phones), so it gets non-negligible. I've also seen people on Discord using entities casually for projectiles / non-hanabi particle systems ([example](https://github.com/abnormalbrain/bevy_particle_systems/tree/main)). 

Napkin math for the amount of memory leaked per 1000 entities spawned/despawned:
- 2d: 1000 x (pipeline entry (8+8+4+8) + entity ticks (8+4)) / 1024 = 39kb
- 3d w/1 directional light: 1000 x (pipeline entry (8+8+4+8) + shadow pipeline entry (8+8+4+8+4+8) x 4 cascades) + entity ticks (8+4)) / 1024 = 183kb

> However, it's also true that applications that are particularly churn-y with respect to spawning/despawning entities could be affected by memory growth. The solution here likely is to expose some kind of mechanism that a particular application could use to flush the rendering caches on some kind of timer and just pay the cost of rebuilding the entire cache. Or when changing scenes, etc.

This would work for me. I don't think the clearing needs to be instantaneous, but there needs to be some strategy to avoid degradation / OOM'ing after sustained use.

Yeah, I gotcha. That seems particularly precarious for memory constrained devices. Let me cook on this a bit and try to throw something together. I may ask you to do some testing on what we come up with to ensure it works for your use case.
Sounds great â€“ thanks! If you get swamped and would like me to take a stab at it, let me know.
Hello, poke from triage. Did anyone end up working on this? Seems like something we should solve before 0.16.
Yes, I have a branch that I need to put up for review.

Just throwing my 2 cents in here that my ios app will spawn and despawn a few thousand entities per-wave of enemies and I've noticed slow memory growth/leaks as well. Would love for this to make it into .16
This will definitely get into 0.16! Just need some time to wrap it up.

issue.title: Remove entities from specialization caches when despawned.

issue.body:
# Objective

Fixes #17872 

## Solution

This should have basically no impact on static scenes. We can optimize more later if anything comes up. Needing to iterate the two level bin is a bit unfortunate but shouldn't matter for apps that use a single camera.

body: Opened a PR that should fix this.
